description: From Middle English pere, from Old English pere, from Proto-West Germanic *peru, from Vulgar Latin *pira, originally the plural of Latin pirum but reconstrued as a feminine singular, ultimately a loanword from an unknown Mediterranean substrate source. Cognate with Saterland Frisian Peere (“pear”), Dutch peer (“pear”), Danish pære (“pear”), French poire (“pear”), German Birne (“pear”), Icelandic pera (“pear”), Swedish päron (“pear”).

entries.meaning: An edible fruit produced by the pear tree, similar to an apple but typically elongated towards the stem.
A type of fruit tree (Pyrus communis).
The wood of the pear tree (pearwood, pear wood).
A desaturated chartreuse yellow colour, like that of a pear.
